triples.statement: While Stalin was described as Asiatic and identified himself as "an Asian, a Russified Georgian," Lenin identified as ethnically Russian and believed European countries like Germany were culturally superior to Russia, which he called a backward Asian country.

triples.sentence: From his youth, Lenin had wanted Russia to become more culturally European and Western.[[280]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2000-280)[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPipes1996-282)
triples.statement: From his youth, Lenin wanted Russia to become more culturally European and Western.

triples.sentence: [Isaac Deutscher](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Isaac_Deutscher "Isaac Deutscher"), a biographer of both Trotsky and Stalin, argued that "[t]he whole testament breathed uncertainty".[[283]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-283)
triples.statement: Isaac Deutscher, a biographer of both Trotsky and Stalin, argued that Lenin's testament "breathed uncertainty."

triples.sentence: Leninist socialists remain divided in their views on Stalin.[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20045-284)
triples.statement: Leninist socialists have divided views on Stalin.

triples.sentence: Some view him as Lenin's authentic successor while others believe he betrayed Lenin's ideas by deviating from them.[[284]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService20045-284)
triples.statement: Some consider Stalin to be Lenin's true successor, while others believe he betrayed Lenin's ideas.

triples.sentence: The socio-economic nature of Stalin's Soviet Union has also been much debated, varyingly being labelled a form of [bureaucratic collectivism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bureaucratic_collectivism "Bureaucratic collectivism"), state capitalism, state socialism or a totally unique [mode of production](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mode_of_production "Mode of production").[[285]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTESandle1999265%E2%80%93266-285)
triples.statement: The socio-economic nature of the Soviet Union under Stalin is widely debated, with descriptions including bureaucratic collectivism, state capitalism, state socialism, or a unique mode of production.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=19 "Edit section: Vladimir Lenin")]

Marx chronicled a history of development through a capitalist age of industrialization that resulted in the manipulation of the [working class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Working_class "Working class"). This development culminated in the empowerment of a [proletariat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Proletariat "Proletariat") which could benefit from the fruits of industrialization without being exploited. Although he meant his ideology to appeal to the disenfranchised working class of an industrialized society, it was widely accepted by developing countries that had yet to successfully industrialize.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247) This resulted in stagnant economies and socialist states without the necessary organization and structure to industrialize.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247) Seeing the failure of those models, Lenin concluded that socialism in Russia had to be constructed from above through party dictatorship that appealed to both the working class and peasants.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) Because the working class accounted for only 15% of the population, Lenin was forced to appeal to the much greater peasant class (accounting for nearly 80%) to propel the Bolshevik faction of Russian Social Democratic Labour Party that under Lenin eventually became the [Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_Communist_Party_(Bolsheviks) "Russian Communist Party (Bolsheviks)") due to a split within social democracy.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247) The Bolsheviks promised "Bread, Peace, and Land" to the peasants and delivered, redistributing land from the landlords and increasing the number of farms in Russia from 427,000 in 1917 to 463,000 in 1919.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247)

For some, Lenin's legacy was one of violent terror and concentration of power in the hands of few.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) Lenin intentionally employed violence as a means to manipulate the population and tolerated absolutely no opposition, arguing that it was "a great deal better to 'discuss with rifles' than with the theses of the opposition".[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) He worked for the ideological destruction of society as a whole so that it could easily adopt the rhetoric and political ideals of the ruling party.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) Lenin's use of terror (instilled by a secret police apparatus) to exact social obedience, mass murder and disappearance, censoring of communications and absence of justice was only reinforced by his successor Joseph Stalin.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) In contrast to those who support this thesis,[[286]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-286) others have disputed this characterization and separated Lenin from Stalin and Leninism from Stalinism.[[287]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-287) A controversial figure, Lenin remains both reviled and revered,[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2012-288) a figure who has been both idolised and demonised.[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERead2005-289) This has extended into academic studies of Lenin and [Leninism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leninism "Leninism") which have often been polarised along political lines.[[290]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-290) While there have been both sympathetic and expressly hostile Lenin's biographies,[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERead2005-289) some sought to avoid making either hostile or positive comments about Lenin, thereby evading politicized stereotypes.[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2012-288)[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee2003-291) Some Marxist activists, who defend both the [October Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/October_Revolution "October Revolution") and [soviet democracy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_democracy "Soviet democracy"), emphasise how the Bolsheviks wanted to avoid terror and argue that the [Red Terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Red_Terror "Red Terror") was born in response to the [White Terror](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/White_Terror_(Russia) "White Terror (Russia)") which has been downplayed.[[292]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-292)[[293]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-293)[[294]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-294)

Lenin has been variously described as "the century's most significant political leader",[[295]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-295) "one of the undeniably outstanding figures of modern history"[[296]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-296) and one of the 20th century's "principal actors"[[297]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2000488-297) as well as "one of the most widespread, universally recognizable icons of the twentieth century"[[298]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERead2005283-298) and "one of the most significant and influential figures of modern history".[[299]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan20125-299) Some historians have characterized Lenin's administration as totalitarian[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fischer-300)[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Shub-301)[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Leggett-302)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1994-303) or a [police state](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Police_state "Police state");[[302]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Leggett-302) or they have described it as a [one-party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/One-party "One-party") dictatorship,[[304]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-304) with Lenin as its dictator,[[289]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERead2005-289)[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fischer-300)[[301]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Shub-301)[[282]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEPipes1996-282)[[305]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-305) although noting differences between Lenin and Stalin in that under the first there was a dictatorship of the party and under the latter that of one man.[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2012-288)[[300]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fischer-300)[[303]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1994-303) Others have argued against the view that Lenin's government was a dictatorship, viewing it as an imperfect way of preserving elements of democracy without some of the processes found in [liberal democratic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Liberal_democratic "Liberal democratic") states.[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2012-288)[[291]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee2003-291) According to the latter view, "the personal qualities that led Lenin to brutal policies were not necessarily any stronger than in some of the major Western leaders of the twentieth century".[[288]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTERyan2012-288)

Among sympathisers, Lenin was portrayed as having made a genuine adjustment of [Marxist theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxist_theory "Marxist theory") that enabled it to suit Russia's particular socio-economic conditions.[[306]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee200314-306) The Soviet view characterised him as a man who recognised the historically inevitable and accordingly helped to make the inevitable happen. Conversely, the majority of Western historians have perceived him as a person who manipulated events in order to attain and then retain political power, moreover considering his ideas as attempts to ideologically justify his pragmatic policies.[[307]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee2003123-307) More recently, [revisionists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Historical_revisionism "Historical revisionism") in both Russia and the West have highlighted the impact that pre-existing ideas and popular pressures exerted on Lenin and his policies.[[308]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELee2003124-308)

section_body:
[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=20 "Edit section: Joseph Stalin")]

Stalin sought to rapidly industrialize the Soviet Union,[[116]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Tucker_1992-116) but perhaps in a way that was unrealistic, given the aggregate skill level and capital of the population[[126]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Keefe_2009-126) and Stalin's argument that the Soviet Union had to accomplish in a decade what England had taken centuries to do in terms of economic development in order to be prepared for an invasion from the West.[[309]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-309) Acknowledging this inadequacy, Stalin ordered that resources slotted for consumption be redirected to production or exported as a temporary sacrifice on the part of the population for the sake of rapid growth.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247) The model was successful initially, with ideology and nationalism promoting morale despite shortages in resources such as food and construction materials for housing. Presumably, the exploited classes believed that once the rapid and successful industrialization of Russia had taken place, power would be relinquished by the [vanguard party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vanguard_party "Vanguard party") and communism would ensue.[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) However, Stalin continued to demand even more far-reaching sacrifices. Because of his control over both political and economic arenas which historians argue gave his vanguard party an amount of control surpassing that of [Russia's tzars or emperors](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Russian_tsar "Russian tsar"), citizens were unwilling to challenge his decrees, given that aspects of their lives such as medical care, housing and social freedoms could be restricted according to the discretion of the party.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247)

Despite failures, Stalin's expectations remained uncontested by the working class and the model was adopted by a multitude of emerging socialist states during that era. The Soviet attempt to [collectivize agriculture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collectivization_in_the_Soviet_Union "Collectivization in the Soviet Union"), transforming the Soviet Union from one of the world's largest exporters of grain to the world's largest importer of grain, was widely replicated despite its failure.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247) Many historians claim that extermination was the fate of a wide variety of people during Stalin's regime such as political opponents, ideological rivals, suspect party members, accused military officers, kulaks, lower-class families, former members of the societal elites, ethnic groups, religious groups and the relatives and sympathizers of these offenders.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247)[[248]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTESchulman2006-248)[[257]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEBrzezinski1989-257) Those deaths occurred as a result of collectivization, famine, terror campaigns, disease, war and mortality rates in the Gulag. As the majority of excess deaths under Stalin were not direct killings, the exact number of victims of Stalinism is difficult to calculate due to lack of consensus among scholars on which deaths can be attributed to Stalin.[[310]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-310)[[311]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-311) However, it is far lower than the estimates of 20 million or above which were made before access to the archives.[[312]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-312)[[313]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-313) Regarding the Holodomor, part of the greater [Soviet famine of 1932–1933](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Soviet_famine_of_1932%E2%80%931933 "Soviet famine of 1932–1933"),[[314]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-314)[[315]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-315) the consensus argues that while Stalin's policies contributed significantly to the high mortality rate, it rejects the view that Stalin or the Soviet government consciously engineered the famine.[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Ghodsee_2014-109)[[316]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDaviesWheatcroft2004-316)[[317]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-317)[[318]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-318) It has been argued that Stalin's "purposive killings" fit more closely into the category of "execution" rather than "murder", given he thought the accused were indeed guilty of crimes against the state and insisted on documentation.[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft19961319%E2%80%931353-319)

Among the [anti-Stalinist left](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-Stalinist_left "Anti-Stalinist left") and [anti-communist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-communist "Anti-communist") Russians and Westerners, Stalin's legacy is largely negative,[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320) with the Soviet Union under him characterised as a totalitarian state[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015-322) and Stalin as its authoritarian leader.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014-323) Various biographers have described Stalin as a [dictator](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dictator "Dictator"),[[324]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-324) an [autocrat](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocracy "Autocracy"),[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Conquest-325)[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) an [Oriental despot](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oriental_despot "Oriental despot"),[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320)[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320)[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Conquest-325) or accused him of practicing [Caesarism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Caesarism "Caesarism").[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) A man who "perhaps [...] determined the course of the twentieth century" more than any other individual,[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Conquest-325) described as "one of the most notorious figures in history"[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) and possessing "that rare combination: both 'intellectual' and killer", the "ultimate politician" and the "most elusive and fascinating of the twentieth-century titans"[[327]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMontefiore2007-327) as well as "one of the most powerful figures in human history",[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) Stalin initially ruled as part of the party oligarchy which he turned into a personal dictatorship in 1934 and became absolute dictator between March and June 1937.[[328]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-328) Stalin later built a "personal dictatorship within the Bolshevik dictatorship",[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014-323) concentrated an "unprecedented political authority in his hands"[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320) and has been described as "closer to personal despotism than almost any monarch in history".[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) Others argued that the campaigns of terror organized by Stalin were driven by his fear of counter-revolution.[[329]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-329)

Other historians and scholars cautioned against "over-simplistic stereotypes" that portrayed Stalin as an omnipotent and omnipresent [tyrant](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyrant "Tyrant") who controlled every aspect of Soviet life through [repression](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Political_repression_in_the_Soviet_Union "Political repression in the Soviet Union") and totalitarianism,[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320) noting that "powerful though he was, his powers were not limitless" and that Stalin's rule depended on his willingness to conserve the Soviet structure he had inherited.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) It has been observed that Stalin's ability to remain in power relied on him having a majority in the [Politburo](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Politburo_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "Politburo of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union") at all times.[[323]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKotkin2014-323) It was noted that at various points, especially in his later years, there were "periodic manifestations" in which the party oligarchy threatened his autocratic control.[[322]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEKhlevniuk2015-322) Stalin denied to foreign visitors that he was a dictator, stating that those who labelled him as such did not understand the Soviet governance structure.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Conquest-325) Several historians have criticized the [totalitarian twins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Totalitarian_twins "Totalitarian twins")[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Ghodsee_2014-109)[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft19961319%E2%80%931353-319) concept and comparisons between [communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism "Communism")/socialism and fascism[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParenti1997-330) or Stalinism and Nazism[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-331) as Cold War concepts[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-332) that focus upon the upper levels of society and which use have obscured the reality of the system.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-333)[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-334)[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-335) Others further noted how the concept became prominent in Western anti-communist political discourse during the Cold War era as a tool to convert pre-war [anti-fascism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-fascism "Anti-fascism") into post-war anti-communism.[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-336)

With the collapse of the Soviet Union and the release of the archives, some of the heat has gone out of the debate and politicization has been reduced. It has been argued that the Soviet political system was not completely controlled from the center and that both Lenin and Stalin only responded to political events as they arose.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-337) Some also questioned the previously published findings that Stalin organized himself the murder of [Sergey Kirov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergey_Kirov "Sergey Kirov") to justify his campaign of Great Terror.[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-338) Others stated that mass deaths from famines are not a "uniquely Stalinist evil" and compared the behavior of the Stalinist regime vis-à-vis the Holodomor to that of the [British Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") (towards Ireland and India) and even the [G8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G8 "G8") in contemporary times, arguing that the latter "are guilty of mass manslaughter or mass deaths from criminal negligence because of their not taking obvious measures to reduce mass deaths" and that a possible defense of Stalin and his associates is that "their behaviour was no worse than that of many rulers in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries".[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021152%E2%80%931172-339) Despite the criticism, Stalin has been considered an outstanding and exceptional politician[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) as well as a great statesman and state-builder,[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320) with some suggesting that without Stalin the Soviet Union might have collapsed long before 1991 as he strengthened and stabilized the country.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) In under three decades, Stalin transformed the Soviet Union into a major industrial world power,[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) one which could "claim impressive achievements" in terms of urbanisation, military strength, education and Soviet pride.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) Under his rule, the average Soviet life expectancy grew due to improved living conditions, nutrition and medical care[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-340) as mortality rates also declined.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021151%E2%80%931172-341)

Although millions of Soviet citizens despised him, support for Stalin was nevertheless widespread throughout Soviet society.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321) Citing those achievements and highlighting crimes committed by the Western world and its leaders during the colonization and imperialist period as well as war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in the 20th century whilst arguing that Stalin's hatred came mainly from [General Secretary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union")[Nikita Khrushchev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita Khrushchev")'s [Secret Speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_Speech "Secret Speech") read during the [20th Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/20th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union") of the [Communist Party of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "Communist Party of the Soviet Union") in February 1956, some have attempted to rehabilitate Stalin and its legacy,[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-342) or otherwise gave a more neutral and nuanced view.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-343)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-344)[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-345) However, those attempts have been criticized and most of its authors labelled as _[neo-Stalinists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Stalinist "Neo-Stalinist")_.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-346)[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-347)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-348)[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-349)[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-350)[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-351) In the 21st century, more than half of Russians view Stalin positively and many support restoration of his monuments either dismantled by leaders or destroyed by rioting Russians during the dissolution of the Soviet Union.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-352)[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-353)[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-354) Stalin's popularity has tripled among Russians in the last twenty years[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-355) and the trend accelerated since [Vladimir Putin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin"), who has been described as holding [neo-Soviet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Sovietism "Neo-Sovietism") views,[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-356) has come to power.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-357)[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-358)

triples.statement: Stalin aimed for rapid industrialization of the Soviet Union, a goal considered unrealistic given the population's skills and capital, and his belief that the country needed to achieve in a decade what England did in centuries to prepare for a Western invasion.

triples.sentence: Acknowledging this inadequacy, Stalin ordered that resources slotted for consumption be redirected to production or exported as a temporary sacrifice on the part of the population for the sake of rapid growth.[[247]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTENugent1992-247)

triples.sentence: Stalin denied to foreign visitors that he was a dictator, stating that those who labelled him as such did not understand the Soviet governance structure.[[325]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Conquest-325)
triples.statement: Stalin denied being a dictator to foreign visitors, claiming that such a label showed a misunderstanding of the Soviet system of governance.

triples.sentence: Several historians have criticized the [totalitarian twins](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Totalitarian_twins "Totalitarian twins")[[109]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Ghodsee_2014-109)[[319]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEWheatcroft19961319%E2%80%931353-319) concept and comparisons between [communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism "Communism")/socialism and fascism[[330]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEParenti1997-330) or Stalinism and Nazism[[331]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-331) as Cold War concepts[[332]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-332) that focus upon the upper levels of society and which use have obscured the reality of the system.[[333]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-333)[[334]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-334)[[335]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-335)
triples.statement: Some historians have criticized the "totalitarian twins" concept and comparisons between communism/socialism and fascism or Stalinism and Nazism, viewing them as Cold War constructs that obscure the system's reality by focusing on the elite.

triples.sentence: Others further noted how the concept became prominent in Western anti-communist political discourse during the Cold War era as a tool to convert pre-war [anti-fascism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-fascism "Anti-fascism") into post-war anti-communism.[[336]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-336)
triples.statement: Others have noted that the concept of "totalitarian twins" was used in Western anti-communist discourse during the Cold War to shift pre-war anti-fascism into post-war anti-communism.

triples.sentence: It has been argued that the Soviet political system was not completely controlled from the center and that both Lenin and Stalin only responded to political events as they arose.[[337]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-337)
triples.statement: Some argue that the Soviet political system was not entirely centrally controlled and that both Lenin and Stalin were reactive to political events.

triples.sentence: Some also questioned the previously published findings that Stalin organized himself the murder of [Sergey Kirov](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sergey_Kirov "Sergey Kirov") to justify his campaign of Great Terror.[[338]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-338)
triples.statement: Some have questioned earlier findings that Stalin personally organized Sergey Kirov's murder to justify the Great Terror.

triples.sentence: Others stated that mass deaths from famines are not a "uniquely Stalinist evil" and compared the behavior of the Stalinist regime vis-à-vis the Holodomor to that of the [British Empire](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/British_Empire "British Empire") (towards Ireland and India) and even the [G8](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/G8 "G8") in contemporary times, arguing that the latter "are guilty of mass manslaughter or mass deaths from criminal negligence because of their not taking obvious measures to reduce mass deaths" and that a possible defense of Stalin and his associates is that "their behaviour was no worse than that of many rulers in the nineteenth and twentieth centuries".[[339]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021152%E2%80%931172-339)
triples.statement: Some argue that mass deaths from famines are not unique to Stalinism, comparing the Holodomor to actions by the British Empire and modern G8 nations, and suggesting a defense for Stalin is that his behavior was comparable to other 19th and 20th-century rulers.

triples.sentence: Despite the criticism, Stalin has been considered an outstanding and exceptional politician[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) as well as a great statesman and state-builder,[[320]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEMcDermott2006-320) with some suggesting that without Stalin the Soviet Union might have collapsed long before 1991 as he strengthened and stabilized the country.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)
triples.statement: Despite criticism, Stalin is also viewed as an exceptional politician, statesman, and state-builder who strengthened and stabilized the Soviet Union, possibly preventing an earlier collapse.

triples.sentence: In under three decades, Stalin transformed the Soviet Union into a major industrial world power,[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)[[326]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Volkogonov1991-326) one which could "claim impressive achievements" in terms of urbanisation, military strength, education and Soviet pride.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)
triples.statement: In less than thirty years, Stalin transformed the Soviet Union into a major industrial world power with significant achievements in urbanization, military strength, education, and national pride.

triples.sentence: Under his rule, the average Soviet life expectancy grew due to improved living conditions, nutrition and medical care[[340]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-340) as mortality rates also declined.[[341]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEllman20021151%E2%80%931172-341)
triples.statement: During Stalin's rule, average Soviet life expectancy increased and mortality rates declined due to better living conditions, nutrition, and medical care.

triples.sentence: Although millions of Soviet citizens despised him, support for Stalin was nevertheless widespread throughout Soviet society.[[321]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEService2004-321)
triples.statement: Despite being despised by millions, Stalin also had widespread support within Soviet society.

triples.sentence: Citing those achievements and highlighting crimes committed by the Western world and its leaders during the colonization and imperialist period as well as war crimes and crimes against humanity committed in the 20th century whilst arguing that Stalin's hatred came mainly from [General Secretary](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union")[Nikita Khrushchev](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nikita_Khrushchev "Nikita Khrushchev")'s [Secret Speech](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Secret_Speech "Secret Speech") read during the [20th Congress](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/20th_Congress_of_the_Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "20th Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union") of the [Communist Party of the Soviet Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communist_Party_of_the_Soviet_Union "Communist Party of the Soviet Union") in February 1956, some have attempted to rehabilitate Stalin and its legacy,[[342]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-342) or otherwise gave a more neutral and nuanced view.[[343]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-343)[[344]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-344)[[345]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-345)
triples.statement: Some have tried to rehabilitate Stalin's legacy or offer a more nuanced view by citing his achievements, comparing his actions to Western crimes, and attributing much of the negative perception to Khrushchev's "Secret Speech" in 1956.

triples.sentence: However, those attempts have been criticized and most of its authors labelled as _[neo-Stalinists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Stalinist "Neo-Stalinist")_.[[346]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-346)[[347]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-347)[[348]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-348)[[349]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-349)[[350]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-350)[[351]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-351)
triples.statement: These attempts at rehabilitation have been criticized, and their authors are often labeled as neo-Stalinists.

triples.sentence: In the 21st century, more than half of Russians view Stalin positively and many support restoration of his monuments either dismantled by leaders or destroyed by rioting Russians during the dissolution of the Soviet Union.[[352]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-352)[[353]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-353)[[354]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-354)
triples.statement: In the 21st century, over half of Russians have a positive view of Stalin and many support restoring his monuments.

triples.sentence: Stalin's popularity has tripled among Russians in the last twenty years[[355]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-355) and the trend accelerated since [Vladimir Putin](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vladimir_Putin "Vladimir Putin"), who has been described as holding [neo-Soviet](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Sovietism "Neo-Sovietism") views,[[356]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-356) has come to power.[[357]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-357)[[358]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-358)
triples.statement: Stalin's popularity in Russia has tripled in the last two decades, a trend that has accelerated since Vladimir Putin, who is described as holding neo-Soviet views, came to power.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=21 "Edit section: China")]

[![Image 15](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9b/Mao_Tse_Tung.jpg/250px-Mao_Tse_Tung.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Mao_Tse_Tung.jpg)

Mao Zedong

Following the fall of the elite, [land-owning class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Landlord "Landlord") of the early 20th century, China began its [Communist Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Revolution "Chinese Communist Revolution") through the countryside. As relationships between agrarian masses and state-controlled programs splintered, the [Chinese Communist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_Communist_Party "Chinese Communist Party") led by Mao Zedong began seizing power.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Meeze-359) In his 1949 essay _On People's Democratic Dictatorship_, Mao committed himself and the Chinese state to the creation of a strong state power with increased economic control.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Meeze-359) He stressed the importance of an authoritarian state, where political order and unity could be established and maintained. Mao committed himself to unification in the vein of complete system overthrow.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Meeze-359) As [party chairman](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chairman_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party "Chairman of the Chinese Communist Party"), Mao allowed himself complete control over the structure and execution of the party with his own [cult of personality](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cult_of_personality "Cult of personality"), an almost mythical position as a guardian of wisdom and charisma.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Meeze-359)

With such power, Mao was able to influence popular opinions, allowing his agenda support without going through state-controlled measures. During the Great Leap Forward, an initiative to develop China from an agrarian sector a major industrial powerhouse, Mao relied greatly on his prestige to influence the people.[[359]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Meeze-359) However, the Great Leap Forward proved a failure as widespread crop and irrigation failures led to the 1959–1961 [Great Chinese Famine](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Great_Chinese_Famine "Great Chinese Famine"). There was no suggested end to the revolution—it was meant to be a continuing process of empowerment of the [peasant class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peasant_class "Peasant class").[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360) With the aggressive failure of his [Cultural Revolution](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cultural_Revolution "Cultural Revolution"), Chinese support for the party and for Mao waned. Continuing struggles after his death would undermine his socialist system, allowing a more democratic yet still one-party ruled system to continue into today. As there is little agreement over his legacy both in China and abroad, Mao is a controversial figure who has been regarded as one of the most important and influential individuals in modern world history.[[361]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-361)[[362]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-362)

Supporters credit Mao with driving imperialism out of China,[[363]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-363)[[364]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-364) modernizing the nation and building it into a [world power](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/World_power "World power"), promoting the status of women and improving education and health care as well as increasing life expectancy as China's population grew from around 550 million to over 900 million under his leadership,[[365]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEO'Brien2002254-365)[[366]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEEbrey2010327-366) among other achievements.[[367]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGao2008-367)[[368]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEGaltungStenslie2014-368) Conversely, his regime has been called [autocratic](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autocratic "Autocratic") and totalitarian and condemned for bringing about mass repression and destroying religious and cultural artifacts and sites. It was additionally responsible for vast numbers of deaths, with estimates ranging from 30 to 70 million victims through starvation, prison labour and mass executions.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShort2001-369)[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFenby2008351-370) While some critics argue that Mao was dismissive of the suffering and death caused by his policies, or that he was well aware that his policies would be responsible for the deaths of millions,[[371]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-371) others have disputed this.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShort2001-369)[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuncan2009-372)[[373]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-373)

Praised as a political intellect, theorist, military strategist, poet and visionary,[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShort2001-369) Mao has been variously described as a "great historical criminal", "both monster and a genius", who was also "a great force for good",[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Biography-209) a "great leader in history" and a "great criminal"[[372]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEDuncan2009-372) as well as "one of the great tyrants of the twentieth century", comparable to [Adolf Hitler](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adolf_Hitler "Adolf Hitler") and Joseph Stalin,[[374]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTELynch2004230-374)[[375]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-375) with a death toll surpassing both.[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShort2001-369)[[370]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEFenby2008351-370) However, others reject those comparisons, arguing that whereas the deaths caused by Nazi Germany and the Soviet Union were largely systematic and deliberate, the overwhelming majority of the deaths under Mao were unintended consequences of famine, noting that the [landlord class](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mass_killings_of_landlords_under_Mao_Zedong "Mass killings of landlords under Mao Zedong") was not exterminated as a people due to his belief in redemption through thought reform. Mao has been compared to 19th-century Chinese reformers who challenged China's traditional beliefs in the era of China's clashes with [Western colonial powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Western_colonialism "Western colonialism")[[369]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-FOOTNOTEShort2001-369) as well as to [United States President](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/United_States_President "United States President")[Andrew Jackson](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Andrew_Jackson "Andrew Jackson").[[376]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-376)

Similarly, Maoist economics policies are controversial. Supporters argue that life expectancy greatly improved under Mao and that such policies rapidly industrialized China and laid the groundwork for the country's later rise to become an economic superpower.[[208]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-O'Brien,_Gao,_Ebrey,_Galtung-208) Critics argue that policies such as the Great Leap Forward and the Cultural Revolution were impediments to industrialization and modernization that delayed economic development and claim that [China's economy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economy_of_China "Economy of China") underwent its rapid growth only after Maoist policies had been widely abandoned. All in all, both supporters and critics alike generally agree that the human cost has been staggering.[[209]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Biography-209)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=22 "Edit section: Maoism")]

Maoism is an adapted Sino-centric version of [Marxism–Leninism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism "Marxism–Leninism").[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377) While believing in [democratic centralism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_centralism "Democratic centralism"), where party decisions are brought about by scrutiny and debate and then are binding upon all members of the party once implemented, Mao did not accept dissenters to the party's decisions.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360) Through the Cultural Revolution and the [Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campaign_to_Suppress_Counterrevolutionaries "Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries"), Mao attempted to purge any subversive idea—especially capitalist or Western threat—with heavy force, justifying his actions as the necessary way for the central authority to keep power.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)

At the same time, Mao emphasized the importance of cultural heritage and individual choice as a way of creating this national unity. He described his ideal system as "a political situation in which there is both centralism and democracy, both discipline and freedom, both unity of purpose and personal ease of mind and liveliness to facilitate the socialist revolution".[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360) While the system advocates contradiction, Mao believed the state above all could provide the masses with the tools for their own expression, but his own brand of self-expression was wholly manufactured, built largely on replacing traditional practices and artifacts of [Chinese culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chinese_culture "Chinese culture") with his own. Through this, transformation of the people towards an internal party collectiveness was possible.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)

Notably, Mao's authoritarianism was rooted in a collective bottom-up style of empowerment. In his system, the proletariat and peasantry were responsible for rising up against the bureaucracy and capital of the state.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377) Joining the peasant class with the bourgeoisie of the countryside (the land-holding, local farmers), the group was able to stifle the claims to power by the wealthier, urban landowners through the banner of [communism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Communism "Communism"). Only when this collection of [peasants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peasant "Peasant") and [petty bourgeoisie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petty_bourgeoisie "Petty bourgeoisie") existed could Mao grow his own, custom bureaucracy.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377) Once this unity was established, Mao argued that the people were the ones who could control the state, but his government's intense control over the citizenry emphasizes the contradiction in his theory—a contradiction, he maintained, was a necessary reality of their specialized system.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377)

triples.sentence: Maoism is an adapted Sino-centric version of [Marxism–Leninism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Marxism%E2%80%93Leninism "Marxism–Leninism").[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377)
triples.statement: Maoism is an adapted, Sino-centric version of Marxism–Leninism.

triples.sentence: While believing in [democratic centralism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratic_centralism "Democratic centralism"), where party decisions are brought about by scrutiny and debate and then are binding upon all members of the party once implemented, Mao did not accept dissenters to the party's decisions.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)
triples.statement: Although he believed in democratic centralism, where party decisions are binding after debate, Mao did not accept dissent from those decisions.

triples.sentence: Through the Cultural Revolution and the [Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Campaign_to_Suppress_Counterrevolutionaries "Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries"), Mao attempted to purge any subversive idea—especially capitalist or Western threat—with heavy force, justifying his actions as the necessary way for the central authority to keep power.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)
triples.statement: During the Cultural Revolution and the Campaign to Suppress Counterrevolutionaries, Mao used heavy force to purge subversive ideas, particularly capitalist or Western threats, justifying it as necessary for the central authority to maintain power.

triples.sentence: He described his ideal system as "a political situation in which there is both centralism and democracy, both discipline and freedom, both unity of purpose and personal ease of mind and liveliness to facilitate the socialist revolution".[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)
triples.statement: Mao described his ideal system as a political situation combining centralism with democracy, discipline with freedom, and unity of purpose with personal ease of mind to advance the socialist revolution.

triples.sentence: Through this, transformation of the people towards an internal party collectiveness was possible.[[360]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Fetzer-360)
triples.statement: This process was intended to transform the people towards an internal party collectiveness.

triples.sentence: In his system, the proletariat and peasantry were responsible for rising up against the bureaucracy and capital of the state.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377)
triples.statement: In Mao's system, the proletariat and peasantry were responsible for rising up against the state's bureaucracy and capital.

triples.sentence: Only when this collection of [peasants](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Peasant "Peasant") and [petty bourgeoisie](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Petty_bourgeoisie "Petty bourgeoisie") existed could Mao grow his own, custom bureaucracy.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377)
triples.statement: Mao could only establish his own custom bureaucracy after this coalition of peasants and petty bourgeoisie was formed.

triples.sentence: Once this unity was established, Mao argued that the people were the ones who could control the state, but his government's intense control over the citizenry emphasizes the contradiction in his theory—a contradiction, he maintained, was a necessary reality of their specialized system.[[377]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Esh-377)
triples.statement: After this unity was established, Mao argued that the people could control the state, but his government's intense control over citizens highlights a contradiction in his theory, which he claimed was a necessary reality of the system.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=24 "Edit section: Arab world")]

See also: [Arab socialism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_socialism "Arab socialism")

Socialism was introduced into the Middle East in the form of [populist](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Populist "Populist") policies designed to galvanize the working class into overthrowing [colonial powers](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonial_powers "Colonial powers") and their domestic allies. These policies were held by authoritarian states interested in the rapid industrialisation and social equalisation of Arab nations and often were characterised by redistributive or protectionist economic policies, lower class mobilization, charismatic leaders and promises to improve national living standards.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378) Those states were progressive in terms of the colonial development that had occurred thus far. They allowed important political and economic gains to be made by workers, encouraged land redistribution, unseated oligarchical political powers and implemented [import-substituting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Import_substitution_industrialization "Import substitution industrialization") industrialisation development strategies.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)

With the collapse of the Eastern Bloc following the Revolutions of 1989 and the dissolution of the Soviet Union in December 1991 as well as the push for [democratization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratization "Democratization"), many Arab states have moved toward a model of fiscal discipline proposed by the [Washington Consensus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Consensus "Washington Consensus").[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378) Although authoritarian leaders of those states implemented democratic institutions during the 1980s and 1990s, their multi-party elections created an arena in which business elites could lobby for personal interests while largely silencing the lower class.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)[Economic liberalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_liberalisation "Economic liberalisation") in these regions yielded economies that led to regimes built on the support of [rent-seeking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent-seeking "Rent-seeking") urban elites, with political opposition inviting the prospect of political marginalisation and even retaliation.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378) Academics and political scientists have classified Ba'athist Syria as an Arab government that is based on the cold war era model of authoritarian socialism.[[a]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-387)

While some Trotskyists such as the [Committee for a Workers' International](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Committee_for_a_Workers%27_International "Committee for a Workers' International") have included Ba'athist Syria as an authoritarian socialist state when they have had a [nationalized](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nationalized "Nationalized") economy as [deformed workers' states](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Deformed_workers%27_states "Deformed workers' states"),[[387]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-388)[[388]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-389) other socialists argued that the [neo-Ba'athists](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Neo-Ba%27athists "Neo-Ba'athists") promoted capitalists from within the party and outside their countries.[[389]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-390)

triples.sentence: These policies were held by authoritarian states interested in the rapid industrialisation and social equalisation of Arab nations and often were characterised by redistributive or protectionist economic policies, lower class mobilization, charismatic leaders and promises to improve national living standards.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)
triples.statement: Authoritarian states adopted these policies for rapid industrialization and social equalization in Arab nations, often featuring redistributive or protectionist economics, lower-class mobilization, charismatic leaders, and promises to raise living standards.

triples.sentence: They allowed important political and economic gains to be made by workers, encouraged land redistribution, unseated oligarchical political powers and implemented [import-substituting](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Import_substitution_industrialization "Import substitution industrialization") industrialisation development strategies.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)
triples.statement: These states enabled significant political and economic gains for workers, promoted land redistribution, removed oligarchies from power, and implemented import-substituting industrialization strategies.

triples.sentence: With the collapse of the Eastern Bloc following the Revolutions of 1989 and the dissolution of the Soviet Union in December 1991 as well as the push for [democratization](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratization "Democratization"), many Arab states have moved toward a model of fiscal discipline proposed by the [Washington Consensus](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Washington_Consensus "Washington Consensus").[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)
triples.statement: Following the collapse of the Eastern Bloc and the Soviet Union, and influenced by a push for democratization, many Arab states shifted towards the fiscal discipline model of the Washington Consensus.

triples.sentence: Although authoritarian leaders of those states implemented democratic institutions during the 1980s and 1990s, their multi-party elections created an arena in which business elites could lobby for personal interests while largely silencing the lower class.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)
triples.statement: Despite authoritarian leaders implementing democratic institutions in the 1980s and 1990s, the resulting multi-party elections primarily served as a platform for business elites to lobby for their interests, effectively silencing the lower class.

triples.sentence: [Economic liberalisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Economic_liberalisation "Economic liberalisation") in these regions yielded economies that led to regimes built on the support of [rent-seeking](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rent-seeking "Rent-seeking") urban elites, with political opposition inviting the prospect of political marginalisation and even retaliation.[[378]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-New_Authoritarianism-378)
triples.statement: Economic liberalization in these areas produced economies that supported regimes reliant on rent-seeking urban elites, where political opposition could result in marginalization or retaliation.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=25 "Edit section: Resistance to democratisation")]

[![Image 16](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/WOSM-WAGGGS-Arab_Region.svg/250px-WOSM-WAGGGS-Arab_Region.svg.png)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:WOSM-WAGGGS-Arab_Region.svg)

[Arab world](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_world "Arab world")

A great deal of debate has been paid by the field of comparative politics to how the Arab region was able to avoid the [third wave of democratisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Third_wave_of_democratisation "Third wave of democratisation"). A number of arguments have been offered by professionals in the field, ranging from a discussion of prerequisites for [democratisation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Democratisation "Democratisation") not supported by the [Arab culture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Arab_culture "Arab culture") to a lack of democratic actors initiating the necessary democratic transition.

Marsha Pripstein Posusney argues that the "patriarchal and tribal mentality of the culture is an impediment to the development of pluralist values", rendering Arab citizens prone to accept patriarchal leaders and lacking the national unity that many argue is necessary for democratization to be successful.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Regimes_and_Resistance-7) Eva Bellin concedes that the prevalence of [Islam](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Islam "Islam") is a distinguishing factor of the region and therefore must contribute to the region's exceptionalism, "given Islam's presumed inhospitality to democracy".[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Regimes_and_Resistance-7) Posusney argues that this "intrinsic incompatibility between democracy and Islam" remains unproven given that efforts to test this association quantitatively have failed to produce conclusive results.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Regimes_and_Resistance-7) Ethnic divisions in the area have also been cited as a factor as well as a weak civil society, a state-controlled economy, poverty, low literacy rates and inequality.[[7]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Regimes_and_Resistance-7)[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Debating-391)

In his book _Debating Arab Authoritarianism: Dynamics and Durability in Nondemocratic Regimes_, Oliver Schlumberger has argued that there is in fact an international ambivalence toward authoritarianism in the Middle East given that stability is preferred over the uncertainty of democratisation due to the region's oil and gas supplies and the strategic importance of its geopolitical location.[[390]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Debating-391)

triples.statement: Marsha Pripstein Posusney argues that the "patriarchal and tribal mentality" of Arab culture hinders pluralist values, making citizens prone to accept patriarchal leaders and lack the national unity needed for successful democratization.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=26 "Edit section: Africa")]

See also: [African socialism](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_socialism "African socialism")

[![Image 17](https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/ca/L%C3%A9opold_Senghor%2C_Pic%2C_5.jpg/250px-L%C3%A9opold_Senghor%2C_Pic%2C_5.jpg)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:L%C3%A9opold_Senghor,_Pic,_5.jpg)

[Léopold Sédar Senghor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L%C3%A9opold_S%C3%A9dar_Senghor "Léopold Sédar Senghor")

During the [1945 Pan-African Conference](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pan-African_Congress "Pan-African Congress"), calls for increased organization, development and self-determination in the poverty stricken African continent put the impetus on colonial powers to negotiate [national sovereignty](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/National_sovereignty "National sovereignty").[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Mushkat-5) While there were few Marxist movements into the continent, Soviet Union activity spurred anti-imperialist and globalization movements from African countries. The congress established [national liberation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/African_independence_movements "African independence movements") as the main topic of their sessions, emphasizing the elimination and exploitation by the imperialist powers over authentic national sovereignty. However, they did not establish clear social or political parameters for this new liberation.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Mushkat-5)

African leaders consistently viewed socialism as a direct rejection of the [colonial system](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Colonisation_of_Africa "Colonisation of Africa") and in turn dismissed the notion of creating independent capitalist systems throughout the continent. They attempted to infuse various forms of socialism—some Marxist–Leninist, others democratic—into tailored ideologies specific to each country.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Mushkat-5) Once these systems were in place, countries developed towards a "focal institutional" society. According to sociologist William Friedland, societies adopted a totalitarian vision of rule, allowing one-party systems and institutions to "penetrate every sphere of private or public activity".[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Gregor-6)

triples.sentence: However, they did not establish clear social or political parameters for this new liberation.[[5]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Mushkat-5)

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=27 "Edit section: Senegal")]

Senegalese President [Leopold Sedar Senghor](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Leopold_Sedar_Senghor "Leopold Sedar Senghor") was among the first and most vocal African advocates for socialism. Before being elected president, Senghor served as one of nine African delegates to the 1945 French Constituent Assembly, negotiating for the transfer of self-governing and policy-making power through locally elected councils.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-France-392) The measure shortly failed, keeping autonomy from the colonies until the [independence movements](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_colonial_empire#Decolonization "French colonial empire") of the 1960s.

After [Senegalese independence](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/History_of_Senegal#Independence "History of Senegal") in 1960, Senghor's [Union Progresiste Senegalaise](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Party_of_Senegal "Socialist Party of Senegal"), a derivative of the [French Socialist Party](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/French_Socialist_Party "French Socialist Party"), grew massive support throughout the continent.[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Gregor-6) Much of his party's success hinged on his revisionist version of Marxism–Leninism, where he argued that "the major contradiction of Marxism is that it presents itself as a science, whereas, despite its denials, it is based on an ethic".[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Gregor-6) By framing it as an ethic, Senghor was able to remove the strict determinism from the ideology, allowing it to be molded towards an Afro-centric model. His revision proved similar to that of Benito Mussolini as he called on a national movement from and for his one-party-ruled government, arguing: "In a word, we must awaken the National Consciousness. [...] But the government cannot and must not do it all. It must be helped by the party. [...] Our party must be the consciousness of the masses".[[6]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Gregor-6)

triples.sentence: Before being elected president, Senghor served as one of nine African delegates to the 1945 French Constituent Assembly, negotiating for the transfer of self-governing and policy-making power through locally elected councils.[[391]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-France-392)
triples.statement: Before his presidency, Senghor was one of nine African delegates to the 1945 French Constituent Assembly, where he negotiated for the transfer of self-governing power to locally elected councils.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=28 "Edit section: Ghana")]

In the same vein as Senghor, socialist leader [Kwame Nkrumah](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kwame_Nkrumah "Kwame Nkrumah") sought to advance this one-party, nationalized form of socialist obedience. Nkrumah stressed the importance of government-owned property and resources. He maintained that "production for private profit deprives a large section of the people of the goods and services produced", advocating public ownership to fit the "people's needs".[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Kwame-393) To accomplish this, Nkrumah emphasized the importance of discipline and obedience towards the single socialist party. He argued that if people submitted and accepted the singular party's program, political independence would be possible.[[392]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Kwame-393) By 1965, his one-party rule had produced an Assembly entirely made up of his own party members.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Bretton-394)

Nkrumah saw law as a malleable weapon of political power, not as a product of a complex system of political institutions.[[393]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Bretton-394) Ghanaian power structures were dominated and controlled by his hand, but elite landowners questioned the legitimacy of Nkrumah's power. Those elites were only afforded one choice, namely to align with their government if they wanted access to the state. Gradually, those who were not granted or did not desire entrance into the party created regions blocs.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Redl-395) The [Asante](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ashanti_people "Ashanti people") emerged as a regional force capable political sway. With the power to set the agenda, the authoritarian party often clashed with these emerging regional groups, ultimately undermining the one-party system.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Redl-395)

triples.sentence: Gradually, those who were not granted or did not desire entrance into the party created regions blocs.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Redl-395)
triples.statement: Gradually, individuals who were not granted or did not want party membership formed regional blocs.

triples.sentence: With the power to set the agenda, the authoritarian party often clashed with these emerging regional groups, ultimately undermining the one-party system.[[394]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Redl-395)
triples.statement: The authoritarian party, which had the power to set the agenda, frequently clashed with emerging regional groups, which ultimately undermined the one-party system.

[[edit](https://en.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Authoritarian_socialism&action=edit&section=29 "Edit section: Tanzania")]

[Julius Nyerere](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Julius_Nyerere "Julius Nyerere") attempted to socialist reform for [Tanzania](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanzania "Tanzania") following those in [Ghana](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ghana "Ghana") and [Senegal](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Senegal "Senegal"). The tenets of his initiatives were to promote the Tanzanian economy; secure state control over development; create a sole political party called the [Tanganyika African National Union](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanganyika_African_National_Union "Tanganyika African National Union") (TANU) which would be under his control; and share the benefits of all gathered income.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Pratt-396)

The system—called ujaama—became a tool for nationalization of the [Tanzanian](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tanzanian "Tanzanian") people. In the system, all Tanzanains were encouraged to run for office, with no campaign funding allowed. Speeches in the election would not focus on the national issues, but rather on the quality of the individual, each of whom would be closely controlled by TANU.[[395]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-Pratt-396) Structurally, the power was shared along regional boundaries, giving increased policy making power and resource allocation to these regions. Local institutions were downplayed, with leadership organizations often facing subversion from higher governmental structures.[[396]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-397)

The first wave of elections in the [Tanzanian general election](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/1965_Tanzanian_general_election "1965 Tanzanian general election") produced a 100% voting rate for TANU officials.[[397]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-398)[[398]](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Authoritarian_socialism#cite_note-399)
